comments.author: Husires
comments.body: I think you mean adopting it legally as a legal tender, as I believe that there is an African country that has already done that, and some small countries may do that. Although Africa has huge resources, in financial policy it does not represent a significant percentage of the global economy, and if there was any serious warning about Bitcoin in the United States or the European Union, most countries in the world would follow, and the opposite would be true if Bitcoin was banned.

comments.author: mamesso
comments.body: Quote from: Bonny070 on March 22, 2024, 01:28:39 PM bitcoin is a future digital currency, i strongly believes that before BTC celebrate 50 years in existence at least one or two African countries is going to legalis it. because block chain network is expanding every day by day. and most of the countries in Africa have the knowledge BTC how it works.Bitcoin has just managed to set an all-time record after its price managed to reach an All Time High (ATH) above $70,000. The increase in Bitcoin prices is certainly very profitable for investors who have kept it, including El Salvador, which has invested and accepted Bitcoin as a legal tender since 2021. Now El Salvador could become one of the richest countries in the world if the value of Bitcoin continues to rise as has happened in recent times. The policy taken by the El Salvador government of investing by purchasing 1 Bitcoin per day needs to be adopted by African countries to achieve the level of success that El Salvador has achieved. The decision to legalize Bitcoin and accept it as legal tender will certainly attract criticism at the start of the policy, but over time countries investing in Bitcoin will bear fruit. It is possible that African countries that adopt Bitcoin as El Salvador has done can repay their loans to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) if the country has taken out loans before.

comments.author: Maus0728
comments.body: I'm all for prosperity in a country so yes, I am hoping to see a lot of African countries get in line and adopt bitcoin, although I hope that it's not going to be a rich people only kind of prosperity because as it stands, bitcoin is for everyone who can afford to buy a bitcoin so I know for a fact that those that have the money will probably exploit the adoption and make sure that they've got the first place again against other people that really needed the bitcoin. I know that this isn't just a one continent issue though as this kind of inequality is prevalent in many countries too from different continents.I do believe too that bitcoin is a symbol of waking up to the oppression that the masses endure so I'm all for it even more that bitcoin becomes a legal thing and that it's the best thing to happen, I'm sure that each adoption of bitcoin in Africa is going to be a monumental thing.

comments.author: Odohu
comments.created_time: March 22, 2024, 03:03:40 PMLast edit: March 26, 2024, 09:23:15 PM by Odohu
comments.body: Quote from: Bonny070 on March 22, 2024, 01:28:39 PM bitcoin is a future digital currency, i strongly believes that before BTC celebrate 50 years in existence at least one or two African countries is going to legalis it. because block chain network is expanding every day by day. and most of the countries in Africa have the knowledge BTC how it works.It will be hard to know which countries will legalize Bitcoin in Africa and which will not because as government changes, so does policies. As of today Central African Republic has taken the lead in this regards and many other African countries might consider it when they see the successes of CAR over the coming years. When the new government of Nigeria came on board,  expectations were high that they will legalize Bitcoin following some of their policies like lifting the restrictions placed on accounts of some individuals and enterprises who engaged in cryptocurrency.  Well, the joy among crypto lovers of Nigeria was short-lived when the government began their crackdown on cryptocurrency exchanges which they accused of playing a part in messing up the exchange rates of the country, an action that could not address the worsening economy of the country and which many see as exercise in futility. Conclusively, the potential of Bitcoin is great globally and even in Africa and with time, we will have leaders that will be able to embrace it rather than stand against it.
